column14: When a Member is authorizing sharing of the Member Health History with another Health Plan or a Third Party Application via the OAuth 2.0 protocol the Health Plan that is operating the API MAY offer the Member an option to restrict the sharing of sensitive information
column15: When a Member is authorizing sharing of the Member Health History with another Health Plan or a Third Party Application via the OAuth 2.0 protocol the Health Plan that is operating the API MAY offer the Member an option to allow the sharing of sensitive information
column16:
Affirmative with Question was my vote. My question is, did I interpret 42 CFR Part 2 correctly in the Summary to the right? I don't want to case a negative vote on the entire ballot as as I'm sure my question will draw a correct response from the reviewers. Thank you.
The default to the best of my knowledge is that sensitive information is restricted per 42 CFR Part 2 requiring explicit permission to share. The wording in this IG states that the payer may allow the option to restrict which is already the default case. The implication is that it would be shared otherwise.
column17: Did I interpret 42 CFR Part 2 correctly in the Summary?

column16:
The intention of including the EOB in the diagram is unclear. The EOB is not the direct result of the adjudication, then Claim Response The EOB is a patient focused, not provider focused, resource which pulls together the majority of the Claim and ClaimResponse information for the purpose of informing the patient.
Adding the ClaimResponse to the diagram would clarify the roles and contents of the respective resources. 
However neither ClaimResponse nor EOB contain or contribute net-new clinical information to the Patient's health record so their inclusion in the diagram as drawn is unclear. Either a box should be drawn araound hte EOB or ClaimResponse and EOB to indicate that they do not contribute clinical content or they should be removed from the diagram.
column17: The intention of including the EOB in the diagram is unclear

column16: The term SubscriberId is used throughout this page as though it is the unique identifier for the patient (beneficiary) in the eyes of the insurer, which it is not adn this will result in users being confused or mislead - the identifier for the patient to the insurer in the context of their coverage (policy/plan) is the Coverage.identifier. The Coverage.subscriberId is the insurers identifier for the party who signed-on to the policy which in the case of a minor or dependent party will not be the patient, for example it would be their spouse, parent, etc.
column17: The term SubscriberId is used throughout this page as though it is the unique identifier for the patient (beneficiary) in the eyes of the insurer, which it is not adn this will result in users being confused or mislead

column14: For the purposes of this IG there is nothing to prevent a covered entity, such as a Provider, from creating an integration interface or application that they submit for approval and connection to a Health Plan API. In that situation the covered entity operates under the same conditions and authorization processes as any other Third Party Application where any sharing of Member information requires explicit authorization to be given by the member via OAuth2.0.
column16:
The Health Plan API is not necessarily using OAuth2.0.

Suggest that language be included to identify that: 
a) using a health plan API does not provide or permit a claim of conformance to this specification;
b) that a purpose of this specification, and its future iterations, is to aoid the lack of interoperability and unnecessary work and cost associated with providers and health plans creating proprietary APIs.
column17: The Health Plan API is not necessarily using OAuth2.0.

column14: After successfully authorizing an application an Access Token and Optional Refresh Token SHALL be returned to the requesting application.
column15:
The scopes of the access token SHALL be restricted to the authorizing Memeber's information and the scopes approved.
Any subsequent Access Token issued based on the Refresh Token SHALL be restricted (at least) to the same restrictions.
column16:
This should specify that the access token SHALL be restricted to the authorizing Memeber's information and the scopes approved. The latter is somwhow implicit by the use of OAuth 2.0 but the former (restriction to the respective Member) needs to be explicitly required.  
Same omments apply to the refresh tokens.
column17: This should specify that the access token SHALL be restricted to the authorizing Memeber's information and the scopes approved.

column14: Member-authorized sharing of their health history MAY utilize the Patient-everything operation. However, the information returned in a bundle by the operation will be limited to only the member’s information…
column15: [add the following caveat] However, the information returned in a bundle by the operation will be limited to only the member’s information, and bound by any further restrictions based on the scopes of the access token, such as security labels. I.e., information about the Member's related persons (e.g., Contact, Next of Kin, subscriber, dependent) SHALL NOT be returned.
column16: All the restrictions of the access token must be followed in returning results for a bulk export.
column17: All the restrictions of the access token must be followed in returning results for a bulk export.

column14: All search parameters and subsequent filtering of returned information SHALL be controlled by the Provider making the information request. The Payer does not filter information that has been requested by the provider.
column15: All search parameters and subsequent filtering of returned information SHALL be controlled by the Provider making the information request. The Payer does not filter information that has been requested by the provider except for the application of any restrictions based on the scopes of the access token issued to the Provider per applicable law.
column16:
The restrictions expressed in the form of OAuth 2.0 scopes associated with the access token must be enforced as part of the correct implementation of  OAuth 2.0.  
For example, if TEFCA2 is finalized to include Meaningful Choice, if a payer member's Meaningful Choice is to opt-out initially or subsequently to use/disclosure in TEFCA exchange, than the payer must filter that member's information if this exchange is a TEFCA exchange. QUESTION is a provider query via CDS Hooks to a Payer ever conducted through a QHIN as a TEFCA exchange?  Probably not..
column17: The restrictions expressed in the form of OAuth 2.0 scopes associated with the access token must be enforced as part of the correct implementation of  OAuth 2.0.

column14:
When a Card is returned from the CDS Hooks appointment-book service by a Health Plan it will provide the following elements:
- An Access Token for secure access to the Health Plan’s FHIR API
column16:
It is not clear who issues this Access Token and who it is issued to. If this is an OAuth access token, the flow for issuing it and identifying the client to the OAuth server must be clarified. It is also a major flaw from the OAuth perspective that the Access Token which must be known only to the specific client (in order to ensure accounntability) is shared with the CDS service. Generally access tokens should not be known to any party other than the Client and the OAuth Server. 
 
Moreover, it must be clearly stated that this acess token must be restricted only to the Member in question and the recipient must not be able to recover any other members' information using this access token.
column17: It is not clear who issues this Access Token and who it is issued to

column14: Applications are registered with the API Endpoint. The application owner MAY be:
column16: It must be clarified what API endpoint is referenced here. In OAuth 2.0, Applications are registered using the client registration API endpoint. OAuth Dynamic Client Registration must be cited here if that's indeed what is intended.
column17: It must be clarified what API endpoint is referenced here.

column14: Health Plans receive data from many other sources that contribute to a Member’s Health History. In addition to medical claims Health Plans may receive C-CDA documents or HL7 V2 messages, such as Admit, Discharge, Transfer (ADT) Messages.
column16:
Either this IG should provide example workflows where the payers obtained clinical treatment information for a permissible purpose in accordance with applicable law; or it should stipulate that this is an assumption.  

Otherwise, there seems to be a presumption that payers may access and exchange clinical treatment information using this IG's exchange mechanism even if obtained outside of permissible flows - e.g., by purchasing from data miner or a PBM.  Another questionable source of clinical treatment information is where HIEs push all ADT messages to any payer with which a patient has or has had a relationship for no specific HIPAA purpose.  

Generally, health plans are only authorized to receive ADT messages related to Members' case management and care coordination for HIPAA Operations purposes.   https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/45/164.501
column17: Either this IG should provide example workflows where the payers obtained clinical treatment information for a permissible purpose in accordance with applicable law; or it should stipulate that this is an assumption.

column14:
Provider requested Provider-Health Plan Exchange using CDS-Hooks and SMART-on-FHIR 
As a minimum the Health Plan’s FHIR API SHALL limit returned results to the records that are related to the Patient/Member that is:
•The subject of the Provider query.
•The member authorizing the sharing of their information.
column16:
RE "The member authorizing the sharing of their information."
Wrt the definition of HIPAA treatment @https://www.hhs.gov/hipaa/for-professionals/privacy/guidance/disclosures-treatment-payment-health-care-operations/index.html
“Treatment” generally means the provision, coordination, or management of health care and related services among health care providers or by a health care provider with a third party, consultation between health care providers regarding a patient, or the referral of a patient from one health care provider to another"
my understanding was that according to this IG, when a provider requests information from a payer (a 3rd party) about a patient who is the payer's Member, no authorization is required.  Please clarify why "The member authorizing the sharing of their information" is a criteria for permitting disclosure" so that readers understand the policy requirements.
column17: Fix "The member authorizing the sharing of their information."

column14: Provider requested Provider-Health Plan Exchange using CDS-Hooks and SMART-on-FHIR
column15: Assumption: The technical mechanisms by which a Payer determines that a Provider requested Provider-Health Plan Exchange using CDS-Hooks and SMART-on-FHIR is authorized are capable of determining that the requester meets the criteria for disclosure for treatment, payment, and operations as explained at https://www.hhs.gov/hipaa/for-professionals/privacy/guidance/disclosures-treatment-payment-health-care-operations/index.html.
column16:
How does the payer determine that the provider to whom Member information is being pushed has, has had, or will likely have a direct/indirect treatment relationship?  Does this IG assume that any provider's request should be responded to? Per https://www.hhs.gov/hipaa/for-professionals/privacy/guidance/disclosures-treatment-payment-health-care-operations/index.html: A covered entity may disclose protected health information for the treatment activities of any health care provider (including providers not covered by the Privacy Rule). 
How does the payer determine that the covered entity to which Member information is being pushed has a need for that information for payment purposes?  See link above: A covered entity may disclose protected health information to another covered entity or a health care provider (including providers not covered by the Privacy Rule) for the payment activities of the entity that receives the information?
How does the payer determine that the covered entity to which Member information is being pushed meets the following criteria? A covered entity may disclose protected health information to another covered entity for certain health care operation activities of the entity that receives the information if: 
  ○ Each entity either has or had a relationship with the individual who is the subject of the information, and the protected health information pertains to the relationship; and 
The disclosure is for a quality-related health care operations activity (i.e., the activities listed in paragraphs (1) and (2) of the definition of “health care operations” at 45 CFR 164.501) or for the purpose of health care fraud and abuse detection or compliance. (See link above.)
column17: How does the payer determine that the provider to whom Member information is being pushed has, has had, or will likely have a direct/indirect treatment relationship?

column14: Provider requested Provider-Health Plan Exchange using CDS-Hooks and SMART-on-FHIR

column16:
Individual’s Right to Direct the PHI to Another Person https://www.hhs.gov/hipaa/for-professionals/privacy/guidance/access/index.html 

An individual also has a right to direct the covered entity to transmit the PHI about the individual directly to another person or entity designated by the individual.  The individual’s request to direct the PHI to another person must be in writing, signed by the individual, and clearly identify the designated person and where to send the PHI.  A covered entity may accept an electronic copy of a signed request (e.g., PDF), as well as an electronically executed request (e.g., via a secure web portal) that includes an electronic signature.  The same requirements for providing the PHI to the individual, such as the fee limitations and requirements for providing the PHI in the form and format and manner requested by the individual, apply when an individual directs that the PHI be sent to another person.  See 45 CFR 164.524(c)(3).
column17: According to OCR, the Authorization screen must provide the capability for Member to sign when directing that the payer share information with a Third Party, new Health Plan, or an Application….

column14: 1-1-1-3 Bulk FHIR via Alternate Secure Transport: The Patient-everything operation enables the use of Bulk FHIR, using such formats as ND-Json. This IG does not define the alternate secure transport mechanisms that may be used for exchange between Health Plans. However, the IG does allow for the use of Bulk FHIR formats to exchange data for an individual member where the member has authorized that exchange
column15: However, the IG does allow for the use of Bulk FHIR formats to exchange data for an individual member where the member has authorized that exchange in whole or part.  Where a member has restricted Bulk Data Transfer to non-sensitive information, this IG references  emerging efforts to support FHIR DS4P to support filtering of member information being disclosed by a payer's FHIR Server.
column16: Recommend that this IG gives the implementer community notice that capabilities to segment Member information for Bulk Data Transfer are being developed.  Members will be more likely to authorize BDT sharing if they have the ability to exercise their privacy preferences.
column17: Recommend that this IG gives the implementer community notice that capabilities to segment Member information for Bulk Data Transfer are being developed

The listed codes are from http://build.fhir.org/valueset-provenance-agent-type.html. 
informant (Informant) [A person who reported information that contributed to the resource]
custodian (Custodian) [The entity that is accountable for maintaining a true an accurate copy of the original record]
Agent.role is bound to http://build.fhir.org/valueset-security-role-type.html 
NOTE This is a particularly telling example of the issues with the value sets bound to Provenance and AuditEvent agent.type/agent.role.  I.e., identical concepts, which could be postcoordinated with themselves! Definitions are not differentiating. Security WG knows that both the agent.type and agent.role value sets need to be fixed as they munge structural/functional roles with dups. Unfortunately, that's inherited from AuditEvent where there is an arbitrary listing of munged functional/structural roles that are supposedly able to be post coordinated. Suggest that this team work with Security WG to get this critical set of codes straightened out into one clearly for the relevant structural and functional roles played by provenance agents.

column14:
7 Member-Authorized OAuth2 Exchange
After authenticating the Member SHALL be presented with an Authorization screen that enables them to approve the sharing of information with the Third Party, or new Health Plan, Application that has client application credentials registered with the Health Plan.

The Authorization screen MAY provide options to allow the Member to limit the information that is shared with the application. For example, this MAY enable the Member to withhold their demographic or behavioral health information.
column16: Strongly support this consumer control capability.
column17: Strongly support this consumer control capability.

column14:
2-2-2 Member-mediated Information Exchange
The CMS Notice For Proposed Rule Making for Patient access and Interoperability requires that a subscriber to a new health plan SHALL be able to request their information to be passed from their old health plan to their new health plan.

A Member SHALL also be able to use APIs to share information with Third Party Applications. This includes:
•Their health history
•Healthcare network/directory information
•Pharmacy network/directory information
•Prescription Drug Formulary information
column15:
2-2-2 Member-mediated Information Exchange
The CMS Notice For Proposed Rule Making for Patient access and Interoperability requires that a subscriber to a new health plan SHALL be able to request their information to be passed from their old health plan to their new health plan.

The Health Plan SHALL create a Provenance Provenance Record documenting the source of the Member records, the identity of the health plan and the action taken to become the custodian of the data. The updated Provenance record SHALL be passed on to any downstream entity requesting the associated records.

A Member SHALL also be able to use APIs to share information with Third Party Applications. This includes:
•Their health history
•Healthcare network/directory information
•Pharmacy network/directory information
•Prescription Drug Formulary information

The updated Provenance record SHALL be passed on to any downstream entity requesting the associated records.

column15:
New Section 6-8 Handling Security Labels
Health Plans SHALL apply security labels to all generated FHIR Resources with privacy tags indicating, at a minimum:
*The level of confidentiality protection, including "normal" for HIPAA PHI and "restricted" for IIHI governed under Title 38 Section 7332, 42 CFR Part 2, and applicable state privacy laws 
*The sensitivity, including sensitive information governed under HIPAA and other laws
*The governing privacy law (HIPAA, Title 38 Section 7332, 42 CFR Part 2, and applicable state privacy laws)
*The permissible purposes of use under the applicable laws - e.g., Title 38 Section 7332 information, which may only be used for the purposes for which it was disclosed, must be labeled with the permissible purposes upon redisclosure.
Health Plans SHALL persist, enforce, with applied security labels. 
Health Plans SHALL accept, persist, and enforce security labels in the meta of all Resources used in PDex exchanges.
Health Plans SHALL apply persisted security labels to all disclosed Resources.
column16: PDex IG is totally silent on the use of FHIR Security Labels. This is a glaring gap, which must be remediated in order for implementers to comply with applicable laws in an interoperable manner.
column17: PDex IG is totally silent on the use of FHIR Security Labels.

column14:
6-7 Handling Data Provenance
6-7-1 Example Provenance Record for chain of custody
Three examples are provided to deal with four different scenarios:
1.Health Plan receives clinical document (C-CDA) or FHIR Clinical Resource (Encounter, Procedure, Observation, DiagnosticReport, etc.) from a Provider with Provenance resource attached.
2.Health Plan receives clinical document or FHIR Clinical Resource from a Provider with NO Provenance resource attached.
3.Health Plan receives FHIR Resource from another Health Plan as part of a member-authorized exchange of their health history.
4.Health Plan receive a claim from a provider and renders the data into FHIR clinical resources in order to pass information to a provider.

6-7-1-1 Clinical Information with Provenance

The Health Plan SHALL store the Provenance information and maintain the correlation or links to the records the Provenance Record is documenting. The Health Plan SHALL update the Provenance record to add information covering the identity of the health plan and the action taken to become the custodian of the data. The updated Provenance record SHALL be passed on to any downstream entity requesting the associated records.

6-7-1-2 Clinical Information without Provenance

The Health Plan SHALL create a Provenance Provenance Record documenting the source of the records, the identity of the health plan and the action taken to become the custodian of the data. The updated Provenance record SHALL be passed on to any downstream entity requesting the associated records.

6-7-1-3 FHIR Resource from prior Health Plan
The Health Plan SHALL store the Provenance information and maintain the correlation or links to the records the Provenance Record is documenting. The Health Plan SHALL update the Provenance record to add information covering the identity of the health plan and the action taken to become the custodian of the data. The updated Provenance record SHALL be passed on to any downstream entity requesting the associated records.
6-7-1-4 Claim Information from Provider
The Health Plan SHALL create a Provenance Provenance Record documenting the source of the records, the identity of the health plan and the action taken to transform the data to FHIR Clinical Resources. The updated Provenance record SHALL be passed on to any downstream entity requesting the associated records.
column15: The Provenance record or Provenance record URL MAY be sent to a Federated Provenance Store shared by authorized exchange participants to enable retrieval of Provenance Records related to a Member's records regardless of whether the authorized requester is conformant to the PDex IG.
column16:
RE: The updated Provenance record SHALL be passed on to any downstream entity requesting the associated records.
 We are fully supportive of the comprehensive provenance requirements.
 However, there are additional use cases, which would not be supported, and understandably out of scope.
  E.g., Members' Apps and third-party actors are not in scope for requiring support for receiving and storing Provenance information, and maintaining correlations or links to the records the Provenance Record is documenting. These actors are also not required to update the Provenance record to add information covering their identities or their actions on the records, nor are they required to pass the updated Provenance record to any downstream entity requesting the associated records.  
 That said, in an effort to evolve a trusted ecosystem of exchange by leveraging Provenance Records, we suggest that in addition to being capable passing on Provenance Records to any downstream entity requesting the associated records, this IG also include an optional capability for in-scope actors to send the location of their Provenance Records to a Federated Provenance Store. This approach is described in the HL7 Privacy and Security Architecture Framework (PSAF) Volume 3 Provenance, which is being reballoted in September 2019.
 Utilizing this approach would enable downstream recipients of PDex information exchanges, as well as many other information exchanges in which Provenance Records were not conveyed, to search on keys from that information to locate any related Provenance Records (as authorized) rather than try to track that provenance by other means.
 As we see it, there is no need at this juncture to specify the architecture of such a Federated Provenance Store.  There are multiple approaches, including the use of Digital Ledger Technology (Blockchain).  What is important is signaling to the DaVinci and wider community that such a capability is on the horizon, and should be "front of mind" in terms of development and further articulation.
column17: We are fully supportive of the comprehensive provenance requirements.

column16: a Provenance resource is much more valuable if it's created by the "last hop", than if it's simply stored unmodified, and sent along by the data provider. This guide does not adequately ensure that such informed disclosures will take place when proposing widespread dissemination of sensitive data

column16: "Mediate" means to intervene in a dispute between two parties in disagreement.  This term would not make sense under this traditionally recognized definition.   I think the term that should be used is "authorized" or "initiated"
column17: "Mediate" means to intervene in a dispute between two parties in disagreement.   I think the term that should be used is "authorized" or "initiated"

column14: After authenticating the Member SHALL be presented with an Authorization screen that enables them to approve the sharing of information with the Third Party , or new Health Plan, Application that has client application credentials registered with the Health Plan.
column16: How are members made aware of their data’s use if the third party is not a covered entity? For instance, a consumer-facing app not covered by HIPAA?  Insurers’ APIs should check an app’s attestation to: industry-recognized development guidance; transparency statements and best practices; and the adoption of a model notice to patients. This information can provide members’ more confidence in their data’s use. For example: 1) An app developer could choose to assert conformance to Xcertia’s Privacy Guidelines; 2) An app developer could attest to the Federal Trade Commission’s (FTC) Mobile Health App Developers: FTC Best Practices and the CARIN Alliance Code of Conduct; or 3) An app developer could attest to adopting and implementing ONC’s Model Privacy Notice. This concept is supported by the AMA, CHI and the HSCC.
column17: How are members made aware of their data’s use if the third party is not a covered entity? For instance, a consumer-facing app not covered by HIPAA? This concept is supported by the AMA, CHI and the HSCC.

column16: In order to enable a patient to share as they desire (and not beyond), care should be taken to ensure that they can provide the minimum amount desired.  Certain kinds of data  have extra protections under state/federal law and regulation (e.g. substance abuse, behavioral health, HIV status, etc.) – shouldn’t the patient have the ability to specifically address sharing of that info.
column17: In order to properly protect patient privacy of sensitive data, authorization of data must be able to be limited according to patient wishes

column14: SHALL be compiled into a FHIR bundle, a PDF SHALL be created to provide a human-readable version of the bundle and both documents SHALL be attached as a DocumentReference and commited to the patient’s record.
column16: Physicians need to know which medical information will be incorporated into record (i.e., within their workflow or assist in CDS) vs. what will be dropped in human readable format (i.e., PDFs or unstructured notes). This issue continues to burden physicians and contributes to HIT burnout. Preferably this should be done by physician-defined preference and not an ad hoc requirement each time info is set to the physician. Rather than just evaluating the EHR’s capabilityStatement, how can this consistently (across all SMART apps/CDS Hook IG) accommodate physician preference for information display and access?
column17: Physicians need to know which medical information will be incorporated into record (i.e., within their workflow or assist in CDS) vs. what will be dropped in human readable format (i.e., PDFs or unstructured notes). This issue continues to burden physicians and contributes to HIT burnout. Preferably this should be done by physician-defined preference and not an ad hoc requirement each time info is set to the physician. Rather than just evaluating the EHR’s capabilityStatement, how can this consistently (across all SMART apps/CDS Hook IG) accommodate physician preference for information display and access?

column14: Where the EMR does not support the attachment of FHIR Bundles to a DocumentReference record the SMART App SHALL create a human readable PDF version of the selected resources and attach this document to the DocumentReference and commit to the patient’s record. Where the EMR does not support the attachment of PDF Documents to a DocumentRefernece record the SMART App SHALL create an HTML or XHTML document that contains the selected resources and attach this document to the DocumentReference and commit to the patient’s record.
column16: These if/then clauses may contribute to physician HIT burden. This seems to overly compensate for HIT optionality and sacrifice usability. More needs to be done to ensure information is consistently provided to the physician in the most useful way possible and facilitates clinical decision making.
column17: These if/then clauses may contribute to physician HIT burden. This seems to overly compensate for HIT optionality and sacrifice usability. More needs to be done to ensure information is consistently provided to the physician in the most useful way possible and facilitates clinical decision making.

column4: 6-6-3 FHIR Profiles and CDS Hooks Context
column14: The Provider MAY select records from the Health Plan’s FHIR API to be committed to their EMR system. After selecting the relevant data the provider MAYtriggers a write of the selected data to their EMR system.
column16: There should not be an expectation that a physician must trigger a write for every instance. How can physician-defined profiles for data integration be developed such that information follows a predictable path into the EHR without manual intervention? These could be established for “trusted” parties or routine retrievals.
column17: There should not be an expectation that a physician must trigger a write for every instance. How can physician-defined profiles for data integration be developed such that information follows a predictable path into the EHR without manual intervention? These could be established for “trusted” parties or routine retrievals.

column14: Health Plans SHALL accept and retain Provenance records received with data from other sources such as a Member-authorized Payer-to-Payer exchange. When a Health Plan forwards information as a FHIR Resource it SHALL create or update a related Provenance record to reflect the original source, any subsequent data handlers or transformers and the action taken by the Health Plan in it’s handling of the data.
column16: How will provenance terminology be maintained between multiple parties? Provenance metadata hasn’t been standardized. For instance, fundamental wording inconsistencies such as “at home blood pressure” and “Home_BP” or “Provider Smith” and “Dr_Smith_MD” may restrict data usefulness. How will this align with ONC’s proposed provenance data class in the USCDI v1? What value sets will be used to accommodate provenance? Does “create or update” mean a health plan may edit provenance information? How will the original provenance be retained if it is “translated” by multiple parties?
column17: How will provenance terminology be maintained between multiple parties? Provenance metadata hasn’t been standardized. For instance, fundamental wording inconsistencies such as “at home blood pressure” and “Home_BP” or “Provider Smith” and “Dr_Smith_MD” may restrict data usefulness. How will this align with ONC’s proposed provenance data class in the USCDI v1? What value sets will be used to accommodate provenance? Does “create or update” mean a health plan may edit provenance information? How will the original provenance be retained if it is “translated” by multiple parties?

column14: Plan SHALL update the Provenance record to add  information covering the identity of the health plan and the action taken to become the custodian of the data
column16: A concept of “retaining the original terminology and data” should be included here.
column17: A concept of “retaining the original terminology and data” should be included.
